utterances: This is WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
What's a six-letter word that starts with P?
Yep, it's time for the puzzle.
Joining me now is WEEKEND EDITION's puzzle-master Will Shortz.
So, what's going on in your world?
Anything exciting happening in the world of Will Shortz?
Well, I'm going to be on TV this week on the ""Artie Lange Show."" It's a sports comedy show.
Tapes Wednesday night - I think it airs Thursday morning on the Audience Network, and it's also online.
Besides talking about puzzles, I'm going to play table tennis on the air with Artie.
Have you played table tennis on TV before?
I bet you're going to do great.
It came from listener Al Gori of Cozy Lake, New Jersey.
And the challenge was to name a famous American man - first and last names.
I said change the first letter of his first name from T to H and the result will sound like a term for an attractive person.
And the answer was Ted Turner to head turner.
And this week about 750 listeners got it right.
Our randomly selected winner if Vernon Cole of Brownsboro, Alabama.
So, how'd you figure this one out?
My wife and I did it jointly actually.
She got it in the end.
But we went through common names that began with T, trying to think of what we could replace the T with the H and get a meaningful word.
And when we got to Ted, it popped right out.
So, what do you for a living in Brownsboro?
I'm an engineer at a contract research and development firm, a small business that does R&D in a number of areas.
I focus mostly on models for how batteries and fuel cells work and how batteries age.
It's a small town adjacent to Huntsville, which is probably more likely you've heard of Huntsville with all the rocket development history.
So, yeah, very, very pleasant place to live, good amount of arts and outdoor activities with the climate.
So, we really have enjoyed it here.
Well, that sounds like a lovely place.
Vernon, are you ready to play the puzzle?
For this week's puzzle, you'll have to put on your thinking cap, or more accurately your thinking hat.
Every answer is a familiar two-word phrase or name in which the first word starts with H-A and the second word starts with T.
For example, if I said track and field event that involves a heavy weight, you would say hammer throw - hammer starting H-A and throw starting with T.
Number one: an informal woman's garment tied around the neck leaving the arms, shoulders and back bare.
Number two: a small item on a rod in the bathroom.
To perform a tricky surfing maneuver.
International court situated in the Netherlands.
The Hague comes to mind, but what the second part would be...
Liable to be set off by the slightest thing, as a temper.
Someone who gets angry really fast and easy would be said to have a blank temper.
Theme song of the ""Roy Rogers Show.
How about this: woolen fabric used in traditional sports coats.
Words before the chief in a presidential salute.
